On Sun, 23 Mar 2003 14:23:30 -0500, "David Corbin"
<dcorbin@...> said:
>    I'm getting tired of having to pass some objects through 6-8 methods,
>    and it's making method signatures very ugly.
>    The question is, what do folks think about using ThreadLocal to create
>    "per   request  singleton-like"  objects.   By  using  a  common  base
>    TestCase,
>    I could set up the TLS easily enough without overburdening the unit
>    tests, I think.
>    David

I think was you are sensing is a "code smell."  I don't have an opinion
about the TLS you mentioned but I would suggest using this "pain" to
force yourself to refactor some more.  For instance, you could use
Factories, Delegators|Facades, or Proxies instead polluting your API with
unneeded args.

One really good question to ask yourself is "Who can I get to do 'this'
for me?" as opposed to "How could I do 'this'?"  It's a subtle, but
profound, difference.  It pushes the issue off as far as possible of what
object will answer 'this' question or provide 'this' behavior.

Your test (via TDD) is saying, "I want XYZ to do ABC for me.  What will
it need to do that?  InterfaceA, InterfaceB, InterfaceC... Ok -- I will
give those things to it."  In some cases, that may be the thing to do, in
others however it makes more sense for the object you are testing to have
those things implicitly available -- your situation sounds a lot like the
latter.

Hope that helps.
=jason
